body:
Here's an example output:
Replay file: https://github.com/deniz1a/file-uploads/raw/master/OpenRA-2015-05-05T214007Z.orarep
Output of the --replay-chat command: https://github.com/deniz1a/file-uploads/blob/master/chat-output.txt

It currently only outputs to command line.

Now I have some questions. To get time stamps for ingame chat, I convert tick count to seconds by dividing it by 25. This should normally give the relative game time, which would progress slower than real time if there was lag. But the actual output has a discrepancy with real time that I think is not explainable by lag. In the example I posted above, the real game duration is 57 minutes but the calculated last time stamp is at 15 minutes... Why is that so? Can that be because of lag? Are frames skipped in orders? Is there a way to get the real tick count of network orders?
Does ReplayMetadata.GameInfo.StartTimeUtc give the starting time of the game or the recording, which begins in the lobby?
I will also add saving the output to a file and printing teams at game start features. Also showing game result at game end.

Ok start time is the game start and not recording start:
https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/ce1eed6bcc29eb4033ff82589a0d2c9e5afb7735/OpenRA.Game/World.cs#L218

Ok I fixed the timestamps. Now the output looks like this: https://github.com/deniz1a/file-uploads/blob/master/fixed-chat-output.txt

I was using wrong type of ticks to calculate time. There is game tick, which is 40 ms or 25 per second. And then there is network tick which is 120 ms or once every 3 game ticks. The frame number from replay packets corresponds to network tick count. And network tick \* 3 / 25 gives the game time of packets in seconds.
Updated the code. Now it shows team configuration at game start and results at game end. Here's the output: https://github.com/deniz1a/file-uploads/blob/master/chat2.txt
(Not a real request) Would it be possible to also show messages like "xy is defeated"?
It shows all the server messages. Is that sent as a server message? Player disconnected messages are shown for example. And the end result is also shown at the end of the output.

It's a debug message... [ConquestVictoryConditions Line 57](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/12966129a4e412fd2c53eb05b310f30557058521/OpenRA.Mods.Common/Traits/Player/ConquestVictoryConditions.cs#L57)

Here are the outputs of these replays: 
https://www.dropbox.com/s/m9f5mn4pcwn69oa/15%20games.rar?dl=0

outputs:
https://github.com/deniz1a/file-uploads/tree/master/15_games
Maybe I should also add batch extraction parameter... So it could extract all .orarep files in a directory.
Don't review this yet, it's not finished. I may rewrite this.

I will definitely rewrite this, currently it's not using engine's Session.Deserialize method and it's not organized well.. I am thinking of creating a new class in OpenRA.FileFormats called ReplayChat, like the one for replay metadata. So that it can be reused in other places like the replay browser. Also how's this idea: replays should be zip archives like .oramap files. It would contain three files: the actual replay, a text file containing replay metadata and another text file containing chat output... The text files would be automatically generated when the replay is saved...

Also, there are at least two places in engine code where network packets are read. Wouldn't it be better to have a common Packet class or something so it would be unified and reused? And if in the future there were any changes to network code, it would be enough to change it in one place and everything that uses it would be automatically updated...
This has become more of a replay report than just the chat... It contains the complete information about the game.

Updated. It's still not finished but has all the features. --replay-report command has three operation modes:
- Extract from single replay and print the report to the console.
- Extract from single replay and save the report file to the given path.
- Batch extract from a source directory and save report files in given path. If no output path is given, a default directory is created.

Operation mode is determined by the type of arguments. If source path is a directory, batch mode is executed.

The progress display made the code a little more complicated but I think it's useful. Extracting a large number of replays can take a while and it is better to give a visual feedback so the program doesn't look like it's frozen.

Again, it's not finished yet and so not ready for full review. But quick feedbacks would be appreciated.
OK I think this PR is finished now. It needs review.
@abcdefg30: I think debug messages are not sent to other players, so they're not in replays. I don't know if that info can be extracted without running the game.

Here is a compilation of replays I found on the forum, along with their extracted reports. They are organized in folders with links to the forum pages where I downloaded them. The file is 306 MB and contains over 900 replays...

https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_dMvsHPqPZkYW1tUGpxQlAyTFE/view?usp=sharing

Metadata contains timestamp for the outcome. But it's in real time. It would be possible to insert that into the chat but the timestamp would not be accurate because game time flows slower than real time... The network tick number of the outcome would be required.

I could add some checks to ReplayReport.cs to make it more robust against corrupted replay files. Currently it can throw uncaught exception if some fields are missing... But it didn't happen for the 900+ replays i tried this with... So I don't know if that would be necessary...

Here's an example report if you don't want to download the 300 MB file:
https://gist.github.com/deniz1a/a4e852d064fa30e49c74

Made some improvements. Now the results are better formatted and show outcome timestamps. These are in real time and not game time as opposed to chat timestamps. Also, batch extractions should be faster now since GeoIP.Initialize() is called only once in ReplayReportCommand and not for every file in ReplayReport.
Because of the formatting of the results section, reports are best viewed with a monospaced font.
Pinging @ihptru who might be interested in this for http://resource.openra.net
Does it look better with text alignment or not?
Any opinions on whether texts should be aligned? I think it should be aligned for results but not the other stuff. :waits for opinions emoticon:

Looks good to me :+1: / :white_check_mark:
after you "fixed" the aligment and the results being empty when "playing" with spectators only.
I fixed empty Results: section. And about the alignment, it looks ok to me... If there are no objections, I'll leave it as it is.
